NAME: Pertinence
REVIEW: Ryunosuke Naito and Kwen Liew met at Restaurant Antoine in 2011. Ryunosuke is Japanese and has worked in some of the top houses of Paris (Taillevent, Meurice) and Kwen is Malaysian. Together they have created this elegant minimalist setting, depicted by light wood and Knoll chairs, whose understated, cosy vibe is perfectly in keeping with their characters and ethos. In the kitchen, they craft market-fresh dishes overflowing in powerful flavours, brushing the cobwebs off French culinary tradition along the way. Spot-on cooking as the name suggests…
FacilitiesAndServices: American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Don Juan II
REVIEW: Moored by Debilly footbridge, on the Right Bank overlooking the Eiffel Tower, the magnificent Art deco Don Juan II yacht, adorned with wainscoting and thick carpeting, awaits you. Set sail for a 2hr30min cruise with none other than Frédéric Anton, an outstanding captain, at the helm! The chef of the Pré Catelan has selected a few of his emblematic dishes (ravioli langoustines, roast venison with autumn truffles, hot chocolate soufflé) to regale passengers. Meals are served against an ever-changing backdrop as you glide down the Seine, viewing some of the most iconic monuments of the City of Light, commented by the crew, as you wallow in the lap of luxury…
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Great view,Visa credit card

NAME: Yam'Tcha
REVIEW: Adeline Grattard was given and continues to demonstrate a rare gift – a remarkable feel for the ingredients she uses in her cooking. In her restaurant on rue Saint-Honoré, this young chef chooses just two or three ingredients which she then focuses on to the full. Here, you won’t find showy demonstrations of her techniques or any form of ostentation, just subtle, rarely seen combinations which appear completely natural. Trained alongside Pascal Barbot (L’Astrance) and having spent several years working in Hong Kong, she brings together ingredients of extraordinary quality (mainly from France and Asia) – examples include her XO sauce, black rice vinegar, and shellfish jus. All these can be superbly paired with a rare selection of Asian teas (yam’tcha in Chinese translates as “to drink tea”). There’s no set or à la carte menu – just the element of surprise and inspiration that comes from the day’s market-sourced ingredients.
FacilitiesAndServices: Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Automne
REVIEW: Japanese chef, Nobuyuki Akishige, who boasts a 5-star CV with spells at the Atelier du peintre in Colmar, the Vague d’Or in St Tropez with Arnaud Donckele, the K2 in Courchevel and the Pyramide in Vienne, signs seasonal, subtle and disciplined dishes with proper Gallic overtones using top-quality goods. A characteristic bistro interior provides the perfect foil to a legible repertory whose harmony of flavours results from spot on cooking, illustrated by roast duck breast and purée of parsley roots and kalamata olives. Unbeatable value for money. If only there were more neighbourhood hangouts like this!
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: NESO
REVIEW: The endearing and heavily tattooed Guillaume Sanchez crafts high-spirited, no-holds barred cuisine in a fashionably stark interior, depicted by an impossibly high ceiling and sporting a metal façade on the street front. Cold-steamed extractions and fermented vegetables: the chef works only with fish and vegetables, selecting stellar pure-bred French ingredients, to which he adds his inimitable and imaginative hallmark and high-flying technical expertise. Varied flavours and textures, art-directed, if unusual plating, the menu unfolds to reveal little bombshells of flavour and, while some were “disconcerting” to say the least, the food clearly bears witness to the establishment’s bold, distinctive culinary identity.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Les Climats
REVIEW: The location – in the former Maison des Dames des Postes, Télégraphes et Téléphones, which housed the postal and telecommunications operators from 1905 – is unusual! The sumptuous interior embraces Art Nouveau style: old mosaic floors, a ceiling whose arches are embellished with a floral pattern, original brass light fittings, stained glass windows etc. The refined and creative dishes take inspiration in French cuisine. And let's not forget the two large glass-walled cellars, home to one of the most extensive selections of Burgundy wines in France.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Valet parking,Visa credit card

NAME: L'Arcane
REVIEW: Led by Laurent Magnin, the youthful team of L'Arcane has left 39 rue Lamarck to take up residence a little higher up, in the former premises of Chamarré Montmartre. With his dishes, the young chef continues to show all the qualities that we already know he possesses. Technical prowess and flavours are a given – a perfect example being the delightful light pea mousse enhanced with yellow lemon zest and black lemon powder. The time spent here over a meal, whether in the form of a surprise menu or à la carte, is always time well spent. Finally, let's not forget the great wine list, which doesn't hesitate to push the boundaries.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Terrace,Visa credit card

NAME: Lasserre
REVIEW: Close to the Champs-Élysées, this Directoire-style private mansion certainly makes an impression. René Lasserre (d 2006) came to Paris to learn the trade while still a teenager and by the end of his career his restaurant had attained iconic status. This emblem of Parisian gastronomy celebrates its 80th anniversary in 2022. The dining space, located on the first floor, is luxuriously decorated with columns, orchid planters and green plants, silver tableware and knick-knacks, crystal chandeliers, Chinese porcelain etc. Another element that adds to the magic of the place is the remarkable and now famous retractable roof, which can be opened in summer, bathing the tables in natural light. Chef Jean-Louis Nomicos, who knows the establishment well, refines tradition with a dash of personality: stuffed macaroni, black truffles, celery and duck foie gras in a light gratin; "André Malraux" squab, French peas, parmesan emulsion with sage.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Valet parking,Visa credit card

NAME: Frédéric Simonin
REVIEW: Frédéric Simon had long frequented top restaurants and great chefs, from Ledoyen at the Meurice to Joël Robuchon, before he became a Best Craftsman of France in 2019. Out went the black and white geometric lines as Frédéric set about creating a venue of his own with parquet floors, white walls and bevelled mirrors. This “Parisian apartment” (his own words) is the perfect foil to his precise, delicate and poised cuisine – special mention for his stocks and sauces. Not afraid of the odd inventive, even Japanese note, he dares unconventional combinations, particularly in his evening tasting menu (5 or 8 courses). The lunchtime menu is a steal, as is the list of wines by the glass.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Car park,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Visa credit card

NAME: Neige d'Été
REVIEW: Summer Snow – the name is eminently poetic, thus befitting the work of Japanese chef, Hideki Nishi, who trained at Taillevent and the George V in Paris. The oxymoron also hints at the plays on contrast and minimalism that are the hallmark of this craftsman. Painstaking Japanese precision and a repertory as Gallic as the Marseillaise come together in exquisitely curated, subtle recipes with a strong focus on arrivals of fish and vegetables straight from Brittany and barbecued notes. Poised, perfectly judged and rich in counterpoints, the food is as stunning as the snow in summertime…
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Le George
REVIEW:
A magnificent Baccarat chandelier, immaculate white colour scheme and delicate floral arrangements all contribute to the chic yet relaxed decor designed by Pierre-Yves Rochon at this restaurant, where guests are left in no doubt that this is part of the exclusive Four Seasons George V hotel! At the helm of Le George since September 2016, Simone Zanoni has definitely made his culinary mark here with his Italian-inspired dishes.
And although the menu also features delightful maritime-inspired touches, it is Italy that takes pride of place here. Zanoni’s dishes are light and served in small portions, with particular attention paid to the flavours and cooking methods of the Mediterranean. Meals are served in the dining room or in the high-ceilinged veranda enabling guests to enjoy the courtyard setting whatever the weather.
Address: Four Seasons George V, 31 avenue George-V, Paris, 75008, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Valet parking,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: L'Orangerie
REVIEW: In an all-white, Lilliputian venue (18 seats only) within the mythical George V Hotel, the menu is the work of Alan Taudon. His cooking, which is unabashedly healthy with a focus on vegetables, dairy produce and seafood, has voluntarily eschewed meat. The dishes are flavoursome and marvellously flanked by some devilishly enticing desserts. The wine list features a selection of the knockout vintages from the cellar of its illustrious next-door neighbour, Le Cinq.
Address: Four Seasons George V, 31 avenue George-V, Paris, 75008, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Terrace,Valet parking,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Nomicos
REVIEW: Having run the kitchens at Lasserre (one of the temples of classical French cuisine) for many years, Jean-Louis Nomicos is now well installed in this restaurant bearing his name. For this bard of gastronomic tradition, who was born near Marseille and grew up in a world where bouillabaisse is king, culinary arts and techniques are first and foremost about the senses and pleasures of the palate. It is within these parameters that he reveals the full potential of his successful recipes and top-notch ingredients – Mediterranean wherever possible, of course – including his signature macaroni with black truffles and duck foie gras. The contemporary decor provides the perfect foil to this chef’s culinary endeavours.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Valet parking,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Yoshinori
REVIEW: The latest spin-off of chef Yoshinori Morié (formerly Petit Verdot, Encore, L’Auberge du 15) is already a hit! Within the walls of an entirely refurbished former Italian restaurant (bare stone, white rafters, Japanese woodwork, designer lighting, white table linen and chinaware), the chef treats us to refined, vegetable-based, graphic cuisine, presented as a seasonal menu. For instance, tartare of milk-fed Corrèze veal, clams and cauliflower, or monkfish with lotus blossom and mushrooms, or pigeon, cèpes, dates, carrots and combava: so many unabashed odes to elegance and taste. Excellent set lunch menu. Love at first bite.
FacilitiesAndServices: American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Le Sergent Recruteur
REVIEW: Chef Alain Pégouret has inherited his love of precise, painstaking work from Joël Robuchon. To see for yourself, you only have to enter Le Sergent Recruteur, a historical tavern on the Île Saint-Louis that has been converted into a fine dining restaurant. The former chef at Laurent displays an impressive command of his craft. His subtle dishes abound with well-defined flavours – you can sense the solid classical foundations – and linger in the memory on account of their sense of harmony, the sophistication of the jus and sauces, and the perfect cooking of the different elements. This establishment exudes a hushed and elegant atmosphere that artfully brings contemporary design into these old walls. A successful revival.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Tomy & Co
REVIEW: Two minutes from Rue Saint Dominique, this establishment bears the hallmark of Cambodian-born chef, Tomy Gousset, who is forging ahead in a no-holds barred, gleeful approach. A relative latecomer to food (23 years old), he perfected his skills at the Meurice, Taillevent and Boulud in New York. Today he plays a gourmet-bistro score, firmly in tune with his era, placing his “karma” (his own words) at the service of taste and the ingredient in a genuine spirit of local sourcing. His motto: “Simplicity and sophistication”, or, in our words this time: “A slap up good meal”!
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Visa credit card

NAME: Apicius
REVIEW: Housed in a sumptuous 18C private mansion that calls to mind a small palace, Apicius is named after this Ancient Roman epicurean who is said to have written the first cookbook. Chef Mathieu Pacaud is keeping the flame alive at this legendary place with a magnificent terrace that amounts to a remarkably bucolic garden in the city. The dishes perpetuate fine bourgeois tradition and achieve a synthesis between classicism and creativity. Time passes, Apicius changes… but remains!
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Garden or park,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Terrace,Valet parking,Visa credit card

NAME: Jacques Faussat
REVIEW: Jacques Faussat, born in Gers and proud of it, clearly aspires to the simplicity of his childhood roots. A simplicity also passed down by Michel Guérard and above all, Alain Dutournier. Jacques’ meeting with the latter, also born in Gers, proved to be decisive in his career, starting with ten years spent in the kitchen of the Trou Gascon. Hand in hand with chef Geoffrey Rembert, they sign flavoursome cuisine made with intelligently crafted produce in a bid to nurture the flavours and aromas. Eater-friendly prices.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Valet parking,Visa credit card

NAME: Le Pavillon - Hôtel Westminster
REVIEW: Le Pavillon of the Westminster Hotel, a 1930’s luxury hotel and a landmark of the Côte d’Opale, invites diners to take a seat in a hushed dining room, depicted by a black and ochre colour scheme and hung with huge animal-themed tapestries, to sample William Elliott’s creative culinary fare. His surf-turf combinations and his balanced dishes that go straight to the essentials are highly appreciated, such as wild turbot, cherries, almonds and a milk of ‘fishbones’. The terrace overlooks the iconic Canche lighthouse.
Address: Avenue du Verger, Le Touquet-Paris-Plage, 62520, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Car park,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Valet parking,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Le Baudelaire
REVIEW: Relax in this stylish, trendy restaurant, nestling in the heart of an arty, cosy luxury hotel that embodies the new Parisian chic. The dining area is laid out around an inner courtyard with a winter garden where it is heaven to snuggle up with a good book and a cup of tea. A haven of genteel tranquillity illustrated by black lacquered tables, comfy armchairs, loft-inspired windows and sleek white walls. Tuck into the vegetable-focused cuisine by chef Anthony Denon (from La Table du Connétable in Chantilly, another model of classicism), and the decadently enticing desserts by Pierre-Jean Quinonero.
Address: Le Burgundy, 6-8 rue Duphot, Paris, 75001, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Valet parking,Visa credit card

NAME: L'Écrin
REVIEW: “A quest for the perfect blend” could be the motto of the luxurious Écrin located in the Hôtel de Crillon. Sommelier Xavier Thuizat and chef Boris Campanella have reversed their roles, overturning the traditional order of precedence in an unheard of, exciting approach: here the choice of wine determines that of the food! Each diner thus enjoys a personalised experience depending on the wines and number of courses selected. The range of combinations is staggering when you think of the 2,300-strong wine bin. This approach also demonstrates the unorthodoxy, technical agility and perfect harmony between the teams. The chef conjures up elegant dishes, overflowing in character which seek to mirror the wine’s bouquet as much as possible. A unique sensory experience in the finest traditions of French art de vivre.
Address: Le Crillon, 10 place de la Concorde, Paris, 75008, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Valet parking,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Comice
REVIEW: A Canadian couple, Noam Gedalof from Montreal and Etheliya Hananova from Winnipeg, had the brainwave to open their first restaurant in Paris after honing their skills around the world. The chef, formerly of The French Laundry, California, draws his inspiration from Gallic traditions, to which he adds a modern spin. His mission is to highlight seasonal ingredients with the utmost care, tailoring the menu to the produce. This flavoursome score is sampled in a natty modern interior, whose deep blue walls are hung with landscapes by contemporary artists, and with an open kitchen to the rear. The front of house is in the hands of the chef’s warm welcoming wife and the couple certainly lives up to their compatriots’ reputation for good cheer.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: L'Atelier de Joël Robuchon - Étoile
REVIEW: Beyond its two restaurants in the French capital, L'Atelier de Joël Robuchon is literally making its way around the world. This venture was born a stone's throw from the Arc de Triomphe, on the lower level of the Publicis Drugstore on the Champs Élysées. A red and black colour scheme; a long counter along which diners sit on high stools, with a view of the kitchen team as they work; a hushed and meditative atmosphere. The Robuchon brand represents a contemporary approach to fine dining. The menu allows the customer to choose between small tasting portions or regular portions. A final touch that will please wine lovers: all the wines by the glass are served from magnums.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Valet parking,Visa credit card

NAME: Ze Kitchen Galerie
REVIEW: Under its hybrid name, Ze Kitchen Galerie toys with the boundary between art and cuisine. In this pared-back space, furniture and designer tableware coexist with colourful paintings around a glassed-in kitchen that enables you to enjoy the show of the team at work. At the stove, William Ledeuil gives free rein to his passion for the flavours of South-East Asia (Thailand, Vietnam), which provide him with plenty of inspiration. Galanga, ka chai, curcuma, wasabi, ginger… So many herbs, roots, spices and condiments from around the world that brilliantly enhance classic French recipes. His menu – based on fish, broths, pasta, a la plancha dishes – comprises a range of inventive, modern and nicely crafted dishes that will take you on a journey of flavours and colours.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Valet parking,Visa credit card

NAME: Sushi B
REVIEW: On the edge of the delightful Louvois Square, this microscopic restaurant (eight seats only) is well worth a visit. The interior is the quintessence of pared down zenitude: upholstered armchairs, elegant counter, fine glassware, starched cotton napkins and exquisite chopsticks… Marble is omniscient, extending as far as the rest room and the Japanese toilets! However, it is the chef’s talent that draws foodies likes wasps to a hive! This master craftsman works only with the freshest ingredients, crafting them with surgical precision. It is a truly captivating to watch him crafting sushis and makis, all the more so as their flavour then explodes in the mouth, without ever being overpowered by soy or wasabi – his immaculate judgement is truly phenomenal. The complimentary textures and balance of his other dishes are equally awesome.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: L'Arôme
REVIEW: Breathe in an aroma, a perfume, a bouquet… such is the enticing agenda that awaits diners at this elegant establishment near the Champs-Élysées, decorated by interior architect Emma Roux. True to its name, the restaurant has a terrific wine cellar, with 400 carefully selected labels. A devotee of seasonal produce, chef Thomas Boullault prepares refined contemporary cuisine. The set menus change every day according to the market stalls. You will fall under the spell of the delicate, balanced flavours: seared bluefin tuna smoked in hay, veal chop with morels… Aromas, scents and flavours: it's on point!
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Valet parking,Visa credit card

NAME: Alan Geaam
REVIEW: We’ve all heard of the American dream, but Alan Geaam prefers the French version! Having fled his native Lebanon at the age of 10 and settled with his family in the United States, he moved to Paris aged 24 with just one idea in mind: to make his way in the world of gastronomy – his true passion. He started out washing dishes, then became a chef’s apprentice before gaining a place at a cookery school and climbing the rungs of the gastronomic ladder. Now at the helm in his own restaurant, he has exploded on to the culinary scene as he brings together all that he has learned over the years. His original recipes skilfully combine France’s rich heritage with touches from the Lebanon in a true mixing of cultures, and his commitment and passion shine through in each and every dish. A fine dining experience.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Helen
REVIEW: Founded in 2012, Helen has already made a name for itself among the fish restaurants of well-heeled Paris. The menu features only wild fish sourced from fishermen who bring in the catch of the day on small boats, which is then lovingly and simply prepared. Rather than fussy frills, the goal is to enhance natural seafood flavours (the fish is served raw, grilled, seared on a plancha, steamed, etc.) – heaven for seafood lovers! The menu varies depending on availability, for example a carpaccio of seabream with lemon caviar, marinaded sardines, young turbot roasted in sage and pancetta, red mullet à la meunière… Everything is a masterclass in precision and know-how and some fish are even filleted and served tableside. The elegant dining room, perfectly at one with this understated ethos, sports a modern, minimalist vibe… Helen is the quintessence of elegant simplicity.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Valet parking,Visa credit card

NAME: 114, Faubourg
REVIEW: Situated within Le Bristol, this brasserie is truly one of a kind! The interior will win you over at first glance: interspersed with imposing gilded columns, it has large luminescent dahlia motifs on its orange walls. At its heart, a grand staircase opens up, leading down to the lower level where tables rub shoulders with the open kitchens. Chic, shimmering, both bustling and intimate, this place hits all the right notes. As for the food, this is a discreetly original take on the French classics we know and love. Dishes are carefully presented and flavours are beautifully combined. This is a lesson in how things should be done.
Address: Le Bristol, 114 rue du Faubourg-Saint-Honoré, Paris, 75008, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,Mastercard credit card,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: La Grande Cascade
REVIEW: Transformed into a restaurant for the Universal Exhibition of 1900, it mingles Empire, Belle Époque and Art nouveau styles whose bewitching charm culminates in a rotunda dining room with a glazed roof that leads onto a superb terrace. Suits come here to savour the spirit of early 20C Paris and the ‘country’ air of the Bois de Boulogne. Georges Menut lovingly takes care of the establishment, pampering and nurturing its image of grand old lady. However, she has also kept up with the times as the presence of Frédéric Robert, a virtuoso chef, with stints at Le Grand Véfour, le Vivarois and Lucas-Carton (where he worked with Senderens for ten years) bears witness. He has carte blanche to dream up subtle dishes, which bear his hallmark of distinctive flavours, ensuring that this dame remains one the capital’s top gourmet establishments.
FacilitiesAndServices: American Express credit card,Car park,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Terrace,Valet parking,Visa credit card

NAME: Auberge Nicolas Flamel
REVIEW: Was Nicolas Flamel also an alchemist, as well as a rich bourgeois and former owner of the oldest house in Paris (1407)? Historians may disagree, but we have no doubt about chef Grégory Garimbay. This chef with a star-studded CV (Sylvestre Wahid, Alain Ducasse at the Plaza Athénée) transforms his ingredients into culinary gold. Jelly of courgettes and blackberries; field-grown tomatoes, smoked ricotta and sorbet of green zebra tomatoes; blue lobster from Brittany, green peas, shellfish jus: the new master chef of this distinguished establishment signs balanced, modern recipes, whose aromas and flavours are intelligently assembled, resulting in no-frills, down-to-earth, occasionally original dishes, like his chocolate and girolle mushroom tart. Ah! a culinary alchemist indeed!
FacilitiesAndServices: American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Le Jules Verne
REVIEW: Frédéric Anton presides over the fate of this emblematic restaurant on the second floor of the Eiffel Tower. Accessible by a private lift, the magic of this 125m-high dining room instantly bewitches the diner, who is further captivated by the high-flying cuisine. Blue-ribbon produce, delicate, perfectly judged cooking and a knockout wine list – every detail has been puzzled and pondered over. For example, naturally cooked cod, spicy jus, fried garlic and fresh coriander or lamb in an aniseed flavoured jus. When booking ask for one of the tables near the windows, as the view over Paris through the tower’s iron fretwork is nothing short of spectacular.
Address: Tour Eiffel - Avenue Gustave-Eiffel, Paris, 75007, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Great view,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Valet parking,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: MoSuke
REVIEW: Former Top Chef contestant Mory Sacko is now showcasing his talent in the former Cobéa, where the dining room has a brighter feel thanks to its new white colour scheme and light wood furniture and flooring. The restaurant’s name is a fusion of the chef’s first name and that of Yasuke, the first and only African samurai in Japan. The chef successfully mixes his Malian and Senegalese roots, his fascination for Japan and, of course, his passion for French cuisine and techniques, nurtured during stints with Christophe Moret and Thierry Marx. The end result is inspired and original dishes, including successful combinations such as sticky rice with tama-miso and mushrooms, and beef picanha with a tamarind mate sauce.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Visa credit card

NAME: Virtus
REVIEW: A few steps from Aligre Market, the stylish dark blue façade hides a vintage interior dotted with Art deco details. It is now the haunt of a talented couple, Frédéric Lorimier in the kitchen and Camille Gouyer in the dining room. Inspired by his background of excellence (in particular with Arnaud Donckele in Saint Tropez), the chef meticulously, almost surgically crafts dishes using seasonal produce, thanks to flawless technique and exquisitely aromatic sauces: roast langoustines, almost scorched baby broccoli and a gutsy jus or veal sweetbread with confit of shallots and lemon-flavoured jus.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: L'Innocence
REVIEW: From their kitchen opening onto the dining room, two talented chefs, Anne Legrand (L'Atelier Rodier, Le Clarence, Itinéraires) and Clio Modaffari (The Kitchen Gallery, Itinéraires, Frenchie) celebrate the food market and the seasons by means of a six-course surprise menu. Take, for example, the fine Ikejime tuna steak, the fantastically tender supreme of squab, or the excellent Cour d'Armoise chicken with its crispy yet melt-in-the-mouth skin. Carefully selected ingredients, punchy flavours and elegant interplays of textures: the colourful dishes made by this duo, who like to work with vegetables, meat and fish, are a delight from start to finish. Remember to book.
Address: 28 rue de la Tour-d'Auvergne, Paris, 75009, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Aspic
REVIEW: Having left the world of finance to join the Ferrandi school of culinary arts, the chef at this restaurant then gained experience elsewhere (including the Ministry for Foreign Affairs and L’Épi Dupin) before opening his own restaurant in rue de la Tour d’Auvergne. With its retro feel, open kitchen and attentive service, Aspic makes guests feel immediately at ease. The carefully presented dishes are as impressive as the setting: the seven-course surprise menu showcases top-quality ingredients (free-range meat and poultry, line-caught fish from small suppliers, herbs and spices etc, all sourced from as short a supply chain as possible) in subtle, delicate dishes with just the right amount of creativity. Exquisite! br>
Address: 24 rue de la Tour-d'Auvergne, Paris, 75009, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Restaurant H
REVIEW: "H" stands for Hubert Duchenne, a chef who hails from Normandy and has worked for Akrame Benallal and Jean-François Piège (Brasserie Thoumieux). Behind an elegant and discreet façade, there is barely room for 20 diners in this intimate space done out in a chic and cosy decor. You will be treated to a well-devised single set menu that makes all the decisions for you and whose beautifully prepared dishes hit all the right notes. How about a succulent slice of golden-skinned Landes poultry served with a seared leek and celeriac mousseline, or the cockles from Dieppe, doused in a beurre blanc and served with shredded samphire and sucrine lettuce? Inventive and masterful cuisine that is all the more delicious for its exclusive use of premium produce.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Le Chiberta
REVIEW: Le Chiberta à la Guy Savoy sports a black colour scheme, has adopted wine as its symbol and inventiveness as its guiding precept. Softly lit, the swish, understated interior by Jean-Michel Wilmotte is refreshingly and fashionably minimalist. Its most eye-catching feature is undeniably an amazing “vertical wine cellar” which boasts a whopper selection of Burgundy and Bordeaux tipples that adorn the walls like rare books in a library. The cooking of chef Irwin Durand (Joël Robuchon, Bernard Loiseau), supervised by the “boss”, adds a modern twist to tradition (quenelle of pike, suckling pig, veal’s head, foie gras), whilst respecting the seasons. Tasting menus (on themes such as truffles and caviar) and wine pairings.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,Mastercard credit card,Valet parking,Visa credit card

NAME: Armani Ristorante
REVIEW: This restaurant is in an original location on the first floor of the Armani store in St-Germain-des-Prés (not far from the church). The interior is pure and elegant, in the designer's style, of course: a palette of beiges, banquette seating, glossy walls, subdued lighting… Might this be just another shopfront in all but name? On the contrary, this ristorante is one of the best Italian eateries in Paris. Chef Massimo Tringali, former sous-chef at Casadelmar in Porto-Vecchio, works with high-quality ingredients in the spirit of contemporary Italian cuisine. It is fresh, tasty and skilfully done: a fine piece of work.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Trente-Trois
REVIEW: This plush, wainscoted Belle Époque dining room is located at number 33 in a discreet edifice, lining what is known as the Golden Triangle near the Champs Élysées. Michelin-starred chef Sébastien Sanjou (also of Le Relais des Moines in the Var) has a knack for selecting premium produce, with which he composes a voluntarily concise menu, signing subtle, up-to-date, seasonal dishes. His food hits the spot every time from the impeccable cooking and superlative jus and sauces to the delicately judged flavours. We tasted a marvellous risotto of spelt, violet artichokes served iced and as crunchy crisps with a hint of coriander in a delicious jus overflowing in gutsy aromas.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Valet parking,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: L'Atelier de Joël Robuchon - St-Germain
REVIEW: Bathed in a studied semi-darkness, two bars face each other around the central kitchen where the dishes are prepared under the gaze of the guests, who sit at the counter on high stools. An interpretation of the idea of a "chic canteen", a Western version of Japanese teppanyaki and sushi bars, with a menu of "customisable" cuisine in the form of small portions and plates and choice ingredients. Caviar on a soft-boiled egg and smoked salmon in puff pastry; fried whiting "Colbert style" with herb butter: nearly 80 different dishes are served at lunch and dinner. Not forgetting the house staples, king crab ravioli, suckling lamb chops and Joël Robuchon's famous mashed potatoes.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Valet parking,Visa credit card

NAME: Aida
REVIEW: The whitewashed facade of this small bolthole tucked away in a lane blends in so perfectly with its surroundings that you may even miss it entirely! Behind its spruce façade lies a jealously kept secret, namely exquisite Japanese cuisine. The pristine white interior is both elegant and minimalist, in line with the visual charter commonly associated with restaurants in Japan. Take a seat either at the counter (nine seats only) for a close-up view of the teppanyaki griddles or in the small soberly appointed private dining room with its tatami. As you sample a single tasting menu, you will discover subtle, precise cuisine that carefully crafts culinary ties between Japan and France. The seasonings, cooking, carving, cutting, slicing and chopping are all at the service of the main ingredient, which is presented as simply and as artfully as possible. Sashimi, Brittany lobster, chateaubriand steak or sweetbread, cooked on the teppanyaki griddle, and served with fine Burgundy wines, painstakingly selected by the chef. Dutiful, professional service.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Particularly interesting wine list,Visa credit card

NAME: Relais Louis XIII
REVIEW: This edifice, steeped in history, stands on the cellars of the former Grands-Augustins convent and it was here on 14 May 1610, an hour after his father King Henry IV had been assassinated, that Louis XIII learned that he was the next king of France… The memory of this rich heritage lingers on in the ornate dining room which sports half-timbers, bare stone, wainscoting, stained-glass and wall hangings, although the profusion of heirlooms is set off by a few cutting-edge details (glazed cellar, modern sculptures). The setting with a sense of occasion is the perfect foil to the food of chef Manuel Martinez, an ardent champion of Gallic culinary classicism. After training at Ledoyen, the Crillon and the Tour d’Argent, the Meilleur Ouvrier de France (Best Craftsman of France) decided to settle in this prestigious establishment to pursue high-flying French culinary traditions. Enduringly popular with regulars, in particular for the excellent eater-friendly lunchtime prices!
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Valet parking,Visa credit card

NAME: Anne
REVIEW: The Pavillon de la Reine, a magnificent residence in Place des Vosges, is named after Anne of Austria, Queen of France and wife of Louis XIII, who once lived here. In the restaurant, overseen by Mathieu Pacaud, the chef reinterprets classic dishes with skill and real talent, using top-quality ingredients which are full of flavour. An excellent dining experience awaits, whether you choose the intimate and romantic setting of the library lounge or, in fine weather, the lovely verdant courtyard garden.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,Mastercard credit card,Terrace,Valet parking,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Benoit
REVIEW: To immerse yourself in the vibe of a genuine Parisian bistro, venture over the threshold of N°20 Rue St Martin. The establishment first saw the light of day in 1912 and the cheerful banter of the old Paris market hall seems to echo still. Initially a Lyon-styled bistro, it was run by three generations of the Petit family, who nurtured its vintage charm and its woodwork, copper pots, mirrors, velvet banquettes and closely packed tables all reek of Belle Époque Paris. Everything down to the plates bears the B monogram, further adding to the authenticity of this bistro that is light years from the trendy boltholes of today. When the business changed hands and became part of the Ducasse Group in 2005, it lost none of its old-fashioned atmosphere. Proudly and heartily traditional, the recipes feature country produce that is expertly and generously cooked. The menu reads like a turn-of-the-20C cookbook, rich in perennial favourites that you practically never get to taste anymore… except here!
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Visa credit card

NAME: OKA
REVIEW: The Brazilian owner-chef, Raphaël Régo, who boasts an enviable CV (Ferrandi, Joël Robuchon, Taillevent) signs a creative repertory at Oka, underscored by his distinctive culinary identity. He successfully navigates between France (fish from the Vendée coast) and Brazil, always with a focus on outstanding produce. Meals are served in a cosy, smart interior, which sports an open kitchen, where you can admire the artist chef at work. His visually sophisticated and minimalist dishes cleverly play with contrasting flavours (sweet, spicy, acidic) and textures, without ever falling foul of the flaw of showing off! You can trust the insights of the gifted sommelier for his wine pairing suggestions. Exquisitely personal, artfully curated and divinely flavoursome – classy! Love at first bite!
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Valet parking,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: La Scène Thélème
REVIEW: At number 18 Rue Troyon, art, particularly theatrical art, meets gastronomy. In fact, the restaurant is named after the Abbaye de Thélème, a utopia by Rabelais and on some evenings, between 7-8pm, you may be treated to a drama production (50 seats only) before you sit down to dinner. The novelty is such that is sure to prove a hit among the discerning gourmets of Paris. On the food side, Japanese chef, Yoshitaka Takayanagi, and his team sign subtle, delicate dishes, rich in personality and made from first-class produce. High precision work, all the finer thanks to the splendid eater-friendly prices! Hush – the curtain is rising!
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Louis
REVIEW: Near the big department stores, but in a quiet street, this small restaurant nurtures its cosy, intimate vibe. Brittany born Stéphane Pitré is at the helm, after a stint at Senderens, and he pays tribute to his father, grand-father and great grandfather here, all called “Louis”. He crafts distinctive signature menus served in 7 or 9 (small) courses (or in 3 for a quick lunch): tartare of Black Angus beef with blackcurrants and tempura oyster; slow-baked monkfish with Thai spices; roast haunch of veal with smoked burrata cheese from Île-de-France. The food is inventive, spontaneous and in harmony with market availability and the seasons. Polished French fare with a twist; for simpler, more homely bistro fare head to Le Cellier, just two numbers down the street.
Address: 23 rue de la Victoire, Paris, 75009, France
FacilitiesAndServices: American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Baieta
REVIEW: "Here, the bouillabaisse cosies up to the aioli, and the pissaladière (tart with onions, olives and anchovies) competes with the socca (chickpea flatbread), just out of the coal-fired oven." Julia Sedefdjian (formerly of Les Fables de la Fontaine, also in Paris) is now happily thriving in her own establishment. Her colourful and fragrant cuisine is an ode to the Mediterranean (her "Bouillabaieta", a superb take on bouillabaisse, is a must) and fine ingredients, which she selects painstakingly and blends creatively, without forgetting her roots in Nice. The chef now solely proposes a series of surprise set menus. Welcome to Baieta – which means "kiss" in the Nice dialect!
FacilitiesAndServices: American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Lucas Carton
REVIEW: The name refers to the long history of this restaurant: Robert Lucas set up his "Taverne Anglaise" here in 1732; Francis Carton joined their two surnames together in 1925 to come up with the new identity of Lucas Carton, which went on to be awarded three Michelin stars in the 1930s; Alain Senderens, who in 2005 decided to give it his own name in order to fully relaunch it. Today, the establishment has discreetly adopted the new codes of contemporary fine dining. Young chef Hugo Bourny (who has worked at Marsan, Maison Pic and La Vague d'Or, to name but a few) knows how to bring out the essence of fine ingredients with his instinctive cuisine, which draws on the very best of France's terroir – a special mention for the vegetables grown by small-scale farmers. The story continues for this iconic restaurant.
Address: 9 place de la Madeleine, Paris, 75008, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Visa credit card

NAME: Pavyllon
REVIEW: There’s no stopping Yannick Alléno! The latest venture of this chef from the Ile de France region is a real winner with guests and rightly so. Offering space for just thirty guests at the counter (similar to a Joël Robuchon Atelier but with a more hushed feel), the restaurant serves refined, delicate cuisine based around classic recipes. Dishes are blended with interesting flavours and the occasional international influence, such as the tempuras which accompany the main courses. A smart yet relaxed setting in which to enjoy a splendid meal.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Terrace,Valet parking,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Fleur de Pavé
REVIEW: If you liked Itinéraires, you will love Fleur de Pavé, an establishment firmly in the zeitgeist where Sylvain Sendra is pursuing his culinary research with the same enthusiasm and flair as in his previous HQ. He whips up modern dishes that draw inspiration from all over the world, featuring deceptively spontaneous plating and blue-ribbon ingredients, such as the highly exclusive vegetables of Asafumi Yamashita. Rather than bowl us over with flashy technique, the chef seeks to lay the emphasis squarely on flavours, whilst upholding the menu’s promise – for which he has our heartfelt thanks!
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Visa credit card

NAME: Pantagruel
REVIEW: Thirty-something Jason Gouzy, who hails from Rennes, is the epitome of generosity, like Rabelais’ well-known character and the restaurant’s namesake, but he is also subtle. He trained at the Ferrandi School before honing his skills at l’Assiette champenoise, the Bristol and the Baudelaire (Burgundy Hotel). Now alone at the helm, he worked with a fashion designer to create this understated gourmet cocoon, both bourgeois and romantic, in the heart of the lively Sentier district. The theatrically glazed kitchen shines the spotlight on his culinary talent from plays on textures to surf and turf recipes without forgetting smoked ingredients and spices, illustrated by smoked beetroot and sardines or the medley of blue lobster.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Il Carpaccio
REVIEW: In the heart of the Royal Monceau, the corridor leading to your table is embedded with thousands of mother-of-pearl shells, in an elaborate and artistic tribute to the nymphs of Italian Baroque. The dining room, set in what looks like a conservatory painted in spring colours, resembles a genuine winter garden flanked by an alfresco area. In the kitchen, Oliver Piras and Alessandra Del Favero subtly conjure up Italian dishes that are deliciously free of fussy nonsense. Their cooking is meticulous, spot on and flavoursome and aims to highlight the natural tastes and flavours of painstakingly selected star ingredients. The same approach is true of the wine cellar which demonstrates a distinct soft spot for Piedmont and Tuscan wines. The decadent desserts by Quentin Lechat offer a new spin on classic Italian recipes.
Address: Le Royal Monceau, 37 avenue Hoche, Paris, 75008, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Valet parking,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Frenchie
REVIEW: “Frenchy” chef, Grégory Marchand, learned the trade in top international restaurants (Gramercy Tavern in New York, Jamie Oliver's Fifteen in London, Mandarin Oriental in Hong Kong). He has now set up shop in Rue du Nil in a pocket handkerchief venue in the Sentier neighbourhood (bare bricks, beams, stones, view of the kitchen). It is invariably packed to the seams and has attracted a faithful cohort of celebrities. The chef's cooking, perfectly in tune with today’s international inclinations, with the bonus of unusual blends of flavours and savvy food and wine pairings, is fully deserving of its current media hype and success. A cheerful vibe flows between the kitchen and the dining room, embodied by the committed youthful staff, all of which proves that it is possible to offer a fine dining experience that is both fun and laid-back, yet highly professional.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Visa credit card

NAME: Tour d'Argent
REVIEW: (Closed for renovation – reopening scheduled for spring 2023) Founded in 1582, this elegant auberge on the banks of the Seine became a restaurant in 1780. And it was at the turn of the 20C that André Terrail purchased it and had the brilliant idea of raising the building one floor to install a dining room, thus benefitting from one of the best (and unique) views of the Seine and Notre Dame cathedral. The soul of the Tour Argent has moved with the times, and its menu, a veritable palimpsest reinterpreted by MOF (Meilleur Ouvrier de France) chef Yannick Franques, has preserved the memory of several decades of French haute cuisine. Purists can rest assured, however, that the perfectly honed service is as spectacular as ever, crowned by the extraordinary wine cellar, home to around 300,000 bottles.
Address: 15 quai de la Tournelle, Paris, 75005, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,Great view,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Valet parking,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Sushi Shunei
REVIEW: This establishment, entirely devoted to sushis, sports a pared down interior in line with the graphic charter of its Japanese forebears: light wooden furnishings and a counter that seats nine, all of which devoted to a rare gourmet experience. Sushi master, Shunei Kimura, has been unfolding his talents and skill in France for several decades now. All the fish is meticulously selected, aged and filleted with the utmost care, served at just the right temperature (with a rice from Nigata) and flanked by high-precision seasonings. Every mouthful embarks you on an authentic culinary voyage.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Pur' - Jean-François Rouquette
REVIEW: Two contemporary restaurants at the Park Hyatt: Café Jeanne at lunchtime and Pur', a more intimate space, for a really enjoyable dinner. The latter is obviously in keeping with the spirit of the hotel on the rue de la Paix, where luxury is synonymous with refinement, modernity and discretion. Ed Tuttle designed the interior, creating an atmosphere that is both comfortable and private, with just 35 covers. Every last detail has been thought out: the colour palette, the lighting and the space itself – a vast rotunda with a dome and a colonnade encircling it. Here, Jean-François Rouquette (Taillevent, Le Crillon, La Cantine des Gourmets, Les Muses) has found a place worthy of expressing his talent in all its brilliance. There is finesse in the way he marries excellent produce in his creative and inspired cuisine. Pure delight!
Address: Park Hyatt Paris-Vendôme, 5 rue de la Paix, Paris, 75002, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,Mastercard credit card,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Valet parking,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Alliance
REVIEW: Between the Left Bank and Boulevard Saint Germain, this restaurant celebrates the Alliance of two enthusiastic partners in a culinary adventure: Shawn and Toshi, respectively in charge of the dining room and the kitchen. Chef Toshitaka Omiya favours authenticity rather than fancy frills and his cooking is founded on fine seasonal ingredients which he aims to enhance, both for the eye and the tastebuds. His signature dish has become foie gras with pot-au-feu vegetables in ginger. Show-stopping simplicity, subtle blends and flawless craftsmanship depict his cooking, flanked by the decadent, almost wicked inspirations of pastry chef Morgane Raimbaud. One final word for the stripped back interior dotted with discreet nods to Japan that is welcoming and commands a fascinating view of the kitchen.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: ERH
REVIEW: The initials E, R and H stand for water, rice and men in French (eau, riz, hommes): a mysterious and poetic name for this unusual place that shares its premises with a sake shop and a whisky bar. Japanese chef Keita Kitamura (previously of Pierre Gagnaire, among others) creates beautifully crafted market-fresh French cuisine that gives pride of place to vegetables and fish. At lunchtime he serves up some impressive culinary treats for a bargain price (three- or five-course set menus); in the evening, he composes tasting menus in line with the seasons. You might like to opt for food and sake pairings. Diners take their seats in an amazing contemporary space with a large glass roof and a long counter that stretches out in front of the open kitchen, where, as in Japan, the Japanese chef officiates. This is the place to try between the Halles and Montorgueil districts. Such talent, such character!
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Notable sake list,Visa credit card

NAME: L'Archeste
REVIEW: An appealing façade and sleek, minimalist interior (dark brushed-effect painted walls, wooden fittings, large window letting in the light) for this restaurant created by a chef with a passion for produce who worked at Hiramatsu for 18 years, for ten of which he was head chef. He astounds diners with his modern, precise and coherent French cuisine, which casts a spotlight on premium-quality ingredients while doing a beautiful job of staying true to the seasons. No fixed menu here: the set menus change every day in line with the chef's inspiration. The name of this place is an homage to Alain Senderens and his restaurant L'Archestrate, but it is also a clever mix of "artisanal", "orchestra" and "art". In the end, what matters is that you enjoy yourself... and it just so happens that you will.
Address: 79 rue de la Tour, Paris, 75016, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Le Faham by Kelly Rangama
REVIEW: The faham is an orchid native to the island of Réunion, famous for its subtle almond scent. Kelly Rangama (a Top Chef 2017 contestant) chose this flower to symbolise her civil and culinary union with pastry chef Jérôme Devreese and their joint creation: this sleek, elegant restaurant tucked away in the Batignolles district. Here the chef proposes a cuisine that abounds in vibrancy and delicacy, spicy but always subtle, with a touch of exoticism that makes all the difference. An example: her toothfish (fished in La Réunion) with sweet-sour carrots and ginger and a concentrate of tomatoes and crunchy rice. A genuine delight.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Oxte
REVIEW: This pleasant and cosy little restaurant in the Étoile neighbourhood, near the Arc de Triomphe, proposes delicious contemporary cuisine with Mexican influences. French ingredients are infused with condiments, herbs and spices by a talented and passionate Mexican chef who also gets involved with the service. Savvy and skilfully prepared dishes such as monkfish and roasted fennel, pastilla crumble and pastis broth or longfin tuna served ceviche-style with mussels and peppers, are turned out by a chef who cooks and seasons the produce beautifully. This colourful, punchy and well-seasoned food is so good you'll soon be back for more!
FacilitiesAndServices: American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: AT
REVIEW: A stone's throw from the banks of the Seine, this small, quietly unobtrusive restaurant sports a minimalist interior in line with today’s quest for authenticity rather than hot air! Chef Tanaka, formerly of Pierre Gagnaire, is a fan of fresh ingredients and precision. Armed with boundless creativity and imagination, he conjures up enticing dishes that keep us drooling right up to the very end. The vaulted cellar in the basement is home to a wine bar and delivers take-away meals. It is also nice to know that you will always be surprised here, because the single set menu changes regularly.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Bellefeuille - Saint James Paris
REVIEW: Built in 1892, this private mansion looks like a little château surrounded by greenery in the very heart of Paris. It became a hotel in the early 1990s, and it wasn't until 2013 that its restaurant opened to outside customers. This is one of the most exclusive establishments in the capital! Chef Julien Dumas (formerly of Lucas Carton) proposes high-quality cuisine replete with vegetables and seafood, as in the lobster from Les Îles Chausey with rhubarb and fennel flower. But meat lovers will be delighted by his mallard served with buckwheat variations and Andouille de Guéméné pork sausage, which is absolutely sublime. Astutely devised and masterfully prepared dishes to be sampled in a refurbished dining room done out in a natural decor that is perfectly in keeping with the chef's cuisine.
Address: 5 place du Chancelier Adenauer, Paris, 75116, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Car park,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,Garden or park,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Visa credit card

NAME: Qui Plume la Lune
REVIEW: Qui plume la Lune is a picturesque and romantic setting that has treated itself to a makeover for its 10th anniversary. One of the walls bears a quote from William Faulkner: “We ran out into the moonlight toward the kitchen.” Bare stone walls and natural materials (untreated wood, twigs and branches, etc) set the poetic scene. This temple of culinary delicacies is the dedicated work of a team determined to select only the very best produce – in line with a clear environmental ethic, hence the premium organic vegetables. Diners are invited to sample dishes that are a masterclass of expertise and precision, overflowing with vitality, fresh ingredients and flavours. A tasty culinary interlude awaits all who enter this temple of good food.
FacilitiesAndServices: American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Visa credit card

NAME: Agapé
REVIEW: In Ancient Greece, the word agape was used to describe the unconditional love of another. In this restaurant, it now stands as a byword for excellence, authenticity and talent. The menu here celebrates seasonal ingredients that the female Brazilian chef uses to create contemporary international dishes. Even when she lets her talent run wild, her controlled mastery of the cooking process shines through, with a total concentration on the concept of giving pleasure. The decor in the cosy, intimate dining room is defined by soft hues and walls adorned with works by contemporary artists. Agapé’s talent is further showcased by the successful fusion between kitchen and front of house and the astute wine pairing recommendations (the wine cellar features over 600 labels).
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Valet parking,Visa credit card

NAME: Le Violon d'Ingres
REVIEW: Continuity and change in the quest for quality: Christian Constant sold Le Violon d'Ingres to Bertrand Bluy, who also hails from southwest France (Lot et Garonne) and is the owner of Les Papilles (in Paris). Fans can rest assured, because the luxurious, neo-bistro styled establishment and the menu remain a loving tribute to la vieille France. The recipes are the combined work of two gifted and experienced chefs, Alain Solivérès and Jimmy Tsaramanana, who sing an ode to southwest France thanks to first-class produce. Remember to book, as tables get snapped up fast.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Divellec
REVIEW: The famous restaurant of Jacques Le Divellec (1983-2013) is now the lair of Mathieu Pacaud. The culinary theme continues to demonstrate a seafaring slant and the food keeps pace with the tides, paying a fine tribute to first-class seafood, such as sole meunière from small boats with hazelnut butter or wild young turbot from Brittany. Take a seat on the deck and savour the view over the Esplanades of the Invalides. The establishment has even extended its premises into a former bookshop, creating a winter garden-inspired room depicted by woven wicker panels.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Valet parking,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Septime
REVIEW: Always on the lookout for new ideas, the team of Septime led by youthful Bertrand Grébaut stands out by its fresh, confident, always enthusiastic and occasionally even cheeky approach. Septime is the quintessence of the new breed of Parisian restaurants, resolutely hip and trendy, but also unwaveringly committed to good food. In the middle of Rue de Charonne, the venue is the summum of today’s modern codes and its spacious, workshop-cum-loft feel, untreated wooden tables and metal rafters offer a swish version of the current trend for industrial interiors. Slick, professional service. Of course, you may have to wait a while before you can get a foot in the door – in general bookings are made three weeks in advance…
FacilitiesAndServices: Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Sola
REVIEW: Just a stone's throw from the banks of the Seine, looking out onto Notre Dame, and yet here we are in Japan! This is Sola, with its tranquil interior done out in wood and, in the basement, the vaulted cellar with its tables arranged on tatami mats (be sure to remove your shoes). Japanese chef Kosuke Nabeta proposes a delicious fusion of the exacting standards of Japanese cuisine and the wealth of ingredients from rural France. He introduces us to traditional Japanese culinary techniques, which he wields with great skill (smoking, drying, marinating, fermenting, alternative cooking methods etc). Be sure to try his signature dish of foie gras and smoked eel! Harmonious, refined and personal food.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Quinsou
REVIEW: Opposite the legendary culinary school, Ferrandi, Quinsou (a chaffinch in Occitan) chirps a gourmet melody that has every chance of influencing the great chefs of tomorrow. In a modern, sharp-edged interior (cement tiles, bare lightbulbs), the chef, formerly of Sergent Recruteur, Antonin Bonnet, crafts distinctive dishes, which are unencumbered, delicate, sensitive and free of unnecessary frills, allowing the ingredient to shout its name. Line-fished seabass from Saint Jean de Luz, bouilla-thai sauce, Salers fillet of beef with roast cèpe mushrooms, garlic cream with sweet almonds… A single set menu that matches the chef’s enthusiasm.
