NAME: Mavrommatis
REVIEW: Cypriot chef Andreas Mavrommatis and his teams orchestrate generous, well-crafted cuisine inspired by classic Gallic traditions using the best Greek ingredients: spanakopita-style morels, grilled squid and confit of onions in xinomavro, Lozère lamb with halloumi… A Greek culinary adventure that varies according to the season and the whims of the chef in a stylish, minimalist setting that provides the perfect foil to the inspired culinary journey.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Accents Table Bourse
REVIEW: "An accent indicates where a person comes from; it tells us about their country, their region and their history. It is this idea of openness and discovery that I want to uphold, a cuisine made up of encounters and exchanges." These are the words of Ayumi Sugiyama, the Japanese proprietor of this contemporary restaurant with a Scandinavian vibe, as well as its pastry chef. The dishes are a combination of classic fare (succulent hare à la royale in season), more daring creations and subtle experiments with roasted and smoked flavours. From start to finish, balance and precision… as is the case with the owner's desserts and the sommelier's judicious advice. Warm and vibrant service.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Shabour
REVIEW: The man behind Shabour is Assaf Granit, the famous Israeli chef. Already at the helm of Balagan (also in Paris) and owner of a dozen restaurants in Jerusalem and London, he is also a TV chef, whose gigs include hosting the Israeli equivalent of Kitchen Nightmares. He set his sights on this 17C building in a lively neighbourhood between rue Saint-Denis and rue Montorgueil. Here we rediscover his trademarks: a lively atmosphere, rough and ready decoration with metal technical ducts visible on the ceiling, subdued lighting... and, of course, generous and surprising creative cuisine replete with Mediterranean influences, whose freshness gives it wings – for example, carrots with slow-cooked egg, tahimi foam, salmon eggs and tzimmes, or beef cheek and oxtail with mushrooms and polenta or, for dessert, chocolate mousse with olive oil and Maldon salt.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Granite
REVIEW: Heading up this modern restaurant is Tom Meyer, a young chef who earned his stripes at the Hôtel de Ville in Crissier, La Chèvre d'Or in Èze, alongside Anne-Sophie Pic and who was awarded the title of MOF in 2022. He works with a dynamic, close-knit team with a clear vision: zero waste, zero plastic and well-being in the workplace. Through intelligently devised set menus, the chef celebrates well-sourced ingredients such as green asparagus from les Landes roasted on a Japanese BBQ or turbot in a subtle geranium-perfumed champagne sauce. It's fresh, delicate and meticulous: a real treat.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Marcore
REVIEW: After regaling the Pigalle neighbourhood in their Bouillon, Marc Favier and Aurélie Alary have elected to re-offend at the Marcore (a phonetic combination of their first names…), combining their manifold talents. They have created a multi-facetted establishment from the old Versance, on the corner of Rue des Panoramas with a bistro bar downstairs, gourmet nosh upstairs and a takeaway deli on the opposite side of the street. Chef Favier is a fervent believer in feel-good cooking that is technically understated with a spotlight on quality ingredients (John Dory, red tuna, wagyu beef). The result is legible, straightforward and finger-licking good!
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Substance
REVIEW: Matthias Marc – a chef who has honed his skills in a series of prestigious establishments (Le Saint-James in Bouliac, Le Meurice and Lasserre in Paris), and was a semi-finalist in French TV's Top Chef 2021 – serves a single set menu (five, seven or nine courses) that favours short supply chains and fine ingredients (turbot, bonito). The dishes stick close to the seasons and incorporate pleasing nods to his native Jura. Gnocchi cooked with plant charcoal, coulis of fermented watercress and Morteau sausage jus or lobster, cherry tomatoes coated in marrow bone and jus infused with geranium serve to illustrate his creative and readily plant-based signature style. A terrific list of 1 000 wines (including 200 champagnes), mostly organic or natural. Uninhibited, lively cooking: an excellent place.
FacilitiesAndServices: American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Visa credit card

NAME: Contraste
REVIEW: Why the name? This restaurant brings together one chef from Brittany, Erwan Ledru, and one from Perpignan, Kevin de Porre, who are childhood buddies; secondly, the premises combine a stylish vintage vibe set off by contemporary details; and finally, a reference to one of the greatest Selosse champagne vintages. The concise menu (flanked by a lunchtime menu and a tasting menu) unveils up-to-date, meticulous, flavoursome cuisine which calls upon top-drawer seasonal ingredients. The surf and turf combinations are particularly appetising (Brittany lobster and sarrazin wheat; monkfish, shellfish and Spanish chorizo or Spanish pork and Cancale oysters).
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Visa credit card

NAME: Gaya par Pierre Gagnaire
REVIEW: On the site of the former Ferme Saint Simon (an institution dating back to 1933), Gaya par Pierre Gagnaire has all the distinctive signs of a gourmet temple and its bright blue façade and pretty awnings catch the eye, as is often the case of select establishments. An exclusive clientele comes to wind down in the chic brasserie that is fashionably stark but has retained its gleaming copper and magnificent bar. The focus is on good food in a bid to cater to modern French sensibilities with a seafaring slant (carpaccio of seabream, pink radishes and grapefruit; giant langoustine, cream of Paimpol beans, scallion onions) and a fondness for veggies, although meat now also makes the occasional guest star appearance on the menu (“Venetian style” calf’s liver, for example).
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Particularly interesting wine list,Valet parking,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Le Rigmarole
REVIEW: Chef Robert Compagnon and Californian pastry chef Jessica Yang have combined their talents to create this atypical restaurant, which is already hugely popular in Paris. Don't be fooled by the name – it could not be further from the truth! Nothing unnecessarily complicated in this tiny establishment, where conviviality and enjoyment are the order of the day: grilled meats, fresh pasta, nods to Italy, France and Japan, small plates to be shared among friends, chatting with a glass of wine in hand. Top-notch produce, as fresh as it gets.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Nakatani
REVIEW: After a decade working with Hélène Darroze, Shinsuke Nakatani is at the helm of this elegant, restful restaurant, decked in soothing colours and natural materials. Thanks to his acute flair for seasoning, cooking and presentation, this ultra-talented Japanese chef concocts a pedigree French score in tune with the seasons, in which the flavours and textures are seamlessly combined to create a consistent whole. Guests can savour a single set menu (4 dishes at lunchtime, 6 in the evening and which changes every two months), served by a crack team that is as low-profile as it is professional. Given the limited number of seats (just 16), it is advisable to book ahead.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Ogata
REVIEW: Ogata could well be Japan’s other Embassy of Paris. This temple dedicated to Japanese art de vivre is located in a private mansion in the Marais, masterminded by Shinichiro Ogata, a world-famous designer and restaurateur, who seeks “beauty and balance in all things” (his own words). The essentially traditional Japanese food sports an omakase spirit, through a tasting menu comprised of immaculate seasonal produce that is perfectly suited to the restaurant’s suave sophistication. We tasted some remarkable starters (spinach, roast asparagus, fried squid, sashimi of horse mackerel), as was the tamago yaki, a subtly perfumed omelette roll. The best seats are at the counter. Pop into the shop or art gallery before leaving…
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Auguste
REVIEW: In Gaël Orieux's small restaurant – barely 30 covers – the elegant contemporary interior with deceptively simplistic lines exudes an unexpected calm. A chic and "classy" space where you can enjoy a judiciously modern cuisine: "black pearl" cupped oysters, seawater jelly, horseradish mousse, Comice pear; sea bass with tomato compote, orange foam with cinnamon flowers. An enticingly varied menu made using high-quality produce. Gaël Orieux sources his supplies from the market and has made the choice to serve only fish species that are not endangered (black mullet, meagre, pout). As for the wine selection, it offers the opportunity to try something new at a reasonable price.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: La Condesa
REVIEW: La Condesa is a district of Mexico City as well as the restaurant of Indra Carrillo, who came to Paris from Mexico to study at the Paul Bocuse institute before working at leading restaurants such as the Bristol and Astrance. Trained by Meilleur Ouvrier de France chefs (notably fish and bread), Indra also spent time in Japan. Although his techniques are French, his culinary inspiration comes from many different cultures, including Mexico. A perfect example is his sweetcorn agnoletti pasta infused in broth with a spicy Mexican oil which is well on the way to becoming his signature dish. The chic, pared-down interior adds the final flourish.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: ES
REVIEW: This place is run by Takayuki Honjo, a Japanese chef who is a fan of French culture and cuisine. Having trained in prestigious establishments (Astrance in Paris, Quintessence in Tokyo, Mugaritz in the Basque country), he has designed his restaurant down to the smallest detail: a white and pared-down dining room, almost monastic, in which the modern furniture does not seek to attract attention. In this context, the meal resembles a kind of ceremony. Foie gras and sea urchins, or pigeon and cocoa: surprising pairings whose flavours mingle intimately. The harmony of his subtle creations recalls this talented young man's Japanese heritage.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Pages
REVIEW: The passion Japanese chefs show for French gastronomy is once again demonstrated by this surprising restaurant whose bare white brick walls are evocative of the unwritten pages of a book. Ryuji Teshima, alias Teshi, knocked around in top establishments before deciding to pursue his own highly personal and contemporary version of Gallic fare, based on ultra-fresh shellfish and fish from Normandy and Brittany – there is even a small ageing fridge for wagyu beef. The “surprise” menu features an improbable looking mixture of colourful flavours on paper, but which works like a dream in the mouth. High-precision cooking and the occasional use of a small barbecue to add a distinctive charred note. The theatrically visible kitchen is always an intriguing and entertaining sight for diners…
FacilitiesAndServices: American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Cheval d'Or
REVIEW: It is with great anticipation that you stop in front of this bright red façade high up in Belleville (in the east of Paris), having secured a table for one of the two evening services by booking well in advance. In this restaurant under the leadership of an authentic Japanese chef, ensconced with his team behind a long counter, you will get to enjoy fragrant dishes inspired by Japanese cuisine: Japanese binchotan charcoal grill, home-made soy ramen and onigri. Laid-back service from a friendly and dynamic team.
Address: 21 rue de la Villette, Paris, 75019, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Notable sake list,Visa credit card

FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Sellae
REVIEW: On the coattails of Mensae ("table" in Latin) in the 19th arrondissement, Sellae ("chair") is another restaurant in the Thibault Sombardier stable. The chef cooks up modern seasonal cuisine, with a penchant for the South of France and above all for indulgence! In this bistro-style interior, the produce is prepared with real know-how: snail ravioli with grass butter, crispy speck, sweet garlic broth; roast veal, casarecce with mushrooms, vin jaune emulsion...
FacilitiesAndServices: American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Etsi
REVIEW: Mikaela, a young chef of Greek origin, has turned her focus to the cuisine of her childhood, after cutting her teeth in some prestigious establishments. Here, she proposes strikingly fresh mezze with bold touches. The feta, olives, capers, charcuterie, cheeses and olive oil have all come straight from Greece. Enjoy in the exceedingly warm and friendly setting.
FacilitiesAndServices: Credit card / Debit card accepted,Terrace,Visa credit card

NAME: Lai'Tcha
REVIEW: In this annex of Yam'tcha, located at the foot of Église St-Eustache, you can enjoy simple but straight-to-the-point Chinese cuisine that is fragrant and made with fine ingredients. The short menu offers various dim sums, but also fresh home-made noodles, Imperial sautéed beef and an excellent salad of Galician beef, lamb's lettuce and oyster mushrooms.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Terrace,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Le Grand Bain
REVIEW: We love this trendy bistro in the bustling heart of Belleville, which has the feel of an old industrial workshop look, courtesy of its central island counter, glass partitions, untreated materials (brick and concrete) and numbered tables. Tuck into food served as small plates – chalked up on the blackboard – prepared by chef Emily Chia, who prefers to cook with vegetables and grains over meat and fish. The playlist reflects the clientèle of hipster night owls and discerning foodies who flock here.
FacilitiesAndServices: Credit card / Debit card accepted,Visa credit card

NAME: Abri Soba
REVIEW: You may have heard of soba, Japanese pasta made with buckwheat, the reputation of which is currently snowballing around the planet. The chef of this restaurant has made soba his house speciality and serves it lunch and evening in an amazing variety of preparations: hot, cold, in stock or with finely sliced duck. Simply flavoursome – get out your chopsticks!
FacilitiesAndServices: Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Kisin
REVIEW: When a Bib Gourmand chef from Tokyo arrives in Paris, the first thing he does is open a restaurant, tantalising and bewitching our senses. Diners will sample Japanese produce and genuine udon, made in front of the diner. Natural, additive - free ingredients, most of which are imported direct from the Land of the Rising Sun. Healthy, wholesome and succulent.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: 20 Eiffel
REVIEW: In a quiet street a stone’s throw from the Eiffel Tower, this restaurant offers a understated interior full of light. On the menu, you can choose from a range of updated dishes, prepared by two chefs, all of which place the focus on flavour and taste. For example, a delicious fillet of wild Pollock with squash.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: L'Antre Amis
REVIEW: The chef-patron at L'Antre Amis brings passion to his cooking. Using seasonal ingredients, he composes a short up-to-the-minute menu (Landes asparagus, Graubünden meat and devilled egg; cod loin fillet and creamy risotto with early peas), as well as tapas-style dishes for sharing. To be accompanied by your pick from some 200 wines. Pleasant contemporary setting and terrace on a quiet street.

NAME: Pottoka
REVIEW: Pottoka, a breed of pony native to the region, is the mascot of Bayonne's rugby club. Basque ingredients may be omnipresent in the dishes (Bayonne ham, chorizo, ossau-iraty), but the chef's approach tends more towards an unpretentious, creative "bistronomy" that is in tune with the times. A success on all fronts.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Terrace,Visa credit card

NAME: Mandoobar
REVIEW: Good authentic Korean restaurants are not two a penny in Paris, but this little restaurant, where the chef works behind his counter, is one of them: diners look on while Kim Kwang-Loc, as nimble-fingered as he is precise, creates the famous mandu (Korean dumplings) and tuna and beef tartares that make up the bulk of his minimalist menu. Passionate about Korean herbs, he seasons each of his delicate and tasty dishes with addictive flavours, perhaps in a quest to recreate his earliest culinary memories in Korea…
FacilitiesAndServices: Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Brigade du Tigre
REVIEW: Both have trained with William Ledeuil, both are passionate about Asia, having traversed the continent, and now the duo who run the kitchen at Eels have joined forces to celebrate the joyful diversity of Asian cuisine in a bistro-style duplex. The result: small fragrant nuggets to nibble on your own or to share, concocted from quality products...
FacilitiesAndServices: Credit card / Debit card accepted,Wheelchair access

NAME: Les Tables d'Augustin
REVIEW: The Épinettes neighbourhood is home to this delightful little bistro, officiated by a pedigreed young chef (George V, L'Ambroisie...) with a genuine commitment to ecology. His tasty and flavoursome cuisine has plenty of character, and offers excellent value for money – especially at lunchtime. Regularly renewed menu depending on market availability.
FacilitiesAndServices: American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Auberge Pyrénées Cévennes
REVIEW: Chef Pierre Négrevergne is really flourishing in this house that is over 100 years old. He delights diners with his tasty "grandmother's" cooking, which highlights French gastronomic heritage (home-made terrine, blanquette de veau à l'ancienne and grilled rice, millefeuille), served in generous portions. It is still a treat to eat here.

REVIEW: The atmosphere is provided by a modern bistro decor and waiters in red and white striped t-shirts. The beautiful seasonal Italian menu is a treat from start to finish, from the antipasti to the dolci. Spaghetti aglio, olio e peperoncini; orecchia di elefante, patate novelle e salvia – it's authentic and tasty.

REVIEW: This enticing bistro, complete with counter, glazed cellar, wooden chairs and benches, is smart and authentic down to its core. The chef’s concise menu takes you on a whirlwind of flavours, always in tune with the seasons. The starters are to share, followed by generous main courses and desserts. Simple and tasty!

NAME: Les Résistants
REVIEW: These résistants believe that taste and traceability should be the backbone of all food. Indeed, the credo of owner, Florent Piard, is none other than "good food that respects natural cycles! " and he amply proves his case in this cheerful establishment. The concise menu changes daily in keeping with market availability and the prices are never outlandish. Natural wines bien sûr!

NAME: Spoon
REVIEW: On the mezzanine floor of the Palais Brongniart, diners are drawn here by the promise of aromatic spices – tamarind, ginger, coriander, saffron. The chef's dishes are inspired by the Maghreb, India, the Middle East: Doha chickpeas with lemon caviar; amberjack, curry leaves and coconut milk; Fez pastilla with dried fruit, cinnamon and star anise.

NAME: Baca'v
REVIEW: Good wholesome food and a casual, down-to-earth vibe depict Émile Cotte’s approach. After a classical debut, he has decided to follow his own path and now adds a personal spin to bistro classics reworked to suit modern tastes. The regularly renewed slate menu is deliciously affordable and there is also a 5-course surprise menu.

NAME: Les Petits Parisiens
REVIEW: Now presiding over proceedings in the kitchen is Nathan Sindres, who has worked in some top restaurants (Anne-Sophie Pic, Gérald Passedat). This chef with the Midas touch is brilliantly ensuring the continuity of the establishment, cooking up bistro-style cuisine that is still in a delicious and hearty vein but more modern and lighter. Those with a sweet tooth will be tempted by the chocolate mousse, olive oil and fleur de sel.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Aux Plumes
REVIEW: Inspired, tasty and generously - served cuisine, whipped up by a youthful Japanese chef, ex - Astrance and Chamarré Montmartre, is what the lucky diner gets here. The produce is sourced from the best local merchants (next - door butcher Hugo Desnoyer) and the buzzing, friendly atmosphere features tightly packed tables. Don’t think twice!
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Visa credit card

NAME: L'Hommage
REVIEW: In a neighbourhood that is best known for its plethora of Chinese eateries, this establishment stands out from the crowd with its French-style bistronomy and refined decor reminiscent of a Scandinavian-style loft. One can't fault the food, with its quality ingredients and on-point cooking and seasoning – eg the crispy tomato and watermelon tartlet, or the tender chicken flavoured with a tasty coconut milk and curry sauce.
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Clamato
REVIEW: Inspired by the oyster bars of the East Coast of the United States, this outpost of Septime owes its name to a cocktail that is very popular in Quebec, a Bloody Mary of sorts with the addition of clam juice – needless to say, you can try one here! The place has all the makings of a bistronomy hit, with its trendy decor and short menu that puts fish and seafood and vegetables centre stage, and draws on international influences. The ingredients are chosen with great care and prepared as simply as possible, then presented in plates for sharing. Please note that reservations are not possible: first come, first served!
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Le Caillebotte
REVIEW: Chef Franck Baranger composes fresh and thoroughly modern dishes, the secret of which only he holds: marinated mackerel, sweet onion with cloves and pickles in honey; fish from the coast, chard stuffed with einkorn wheat and beurre blanc with dill… It's delicious, colourful, and goes perfectly with the friendly atmosphere of the place.
FacilitiesAndServices: American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card

NAME: Richer
REVIEW: This place appeals as much for its arty "canteen" vibe as it does for its dishes, which showcase a fresh and tasty take on market-inspired cuisine, as in the long-braised beef chuck served on a fine broccoli purée. Bear in mind, though, that the only way to reserve is to show up at the restaurant.
FacilitiesAndServices: Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: 52 Faubourg St-Denis
REVIEW: Fans of neo - bistros are going to love this place with bare concrete and exposed stone, a concise, tempting menu, good wines and craft beers. Nothing is left to chance, down to the coffee, which is selected and roasted by the owner. Bear in mind the place doesn't take bookings and doesn't have a phone.
FacilitiesAndServices: Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access

NAME: Mensae
REVIEW: Cuisine of the moment, full of freshness and with spot-on flavours. Among the classics, on the menu all year round, the frogs' legs, garlic and parsley or the mousse au chocolat praliné are good enough to spark a riot. The decor has the good taste to make itself discreet. The small sidewalk terrace is welcome in summer and the lunch menu is a boon.

The wine list includes some unusual natural wines. A simpler set menu at lunchtime.

All credit to the chef, Mr Te, who arrived in France in 1968 and is a magnificent ambassador for Vietnamese cuisine. Dumplings, crispy chicken with fresh ginger, bo bun and phô soups: everything is full of flavour.

NAME: Mokko
REVIEW: Arthur Hantz, a self-taught chef who started out washing the dishes, has adopted a no-holds barred, complex-free approach and his modern bistro at the foot of Montmartre gets right down to brass tacks. The menu (carte or slate only) features a devilishly effective strategy: creative, vivacious, market-fresh cuisine with the odd Asian influence. A few examples: lightly seared cockles and scallops, pho emulsion, pimangue spice; free-range chicken, vitelotte potato crème, violet cauliflower, roast parsley roots, jus of milk-fed veal and toasted sarrazin.

NAME: Le Radis Beurre
REVIEW: Chef Jérôme Bonnet found the perfect location for his restaurant on Boulevard Garibaldi in Paris. He prepares tasty, well-crafted cuisine that bears the hallmark of his early years in southern France. The pork loin with braised endives, Mimolette Vieille cheese and a pearlescent jus is just one dish that will certainly grab your full attention.
